page.title: 09The Colne Valley - Transport
page.content: The Colne Valley has long provided a route across the Pennines linking Huddersfield and Manchester. The A62 Manchester road was opened in 1821 as part of a turnpike road to replace an old chain road. It carries heavy traffic to Manchester, although the M62 motorway has reduced the amount considerably. The railway connects Huddersfield to Manchester with local stops at Slaithwaite. It was opened in 1849. It has a regular passenger service and carries freight also. It now has two tracks which are not electrified. The Huddersfield Narrow Canal was opened in 1794 linking Huddersfield with Ashton Under Lyme. It was closed in 1944, but is now undergoing restoration. The towpath still provides a popular walk.
